title: 106_hr4708
content: The Act may be cited as the "California Trail Interpretive Center Act" and includes findings and purposes. Congress finds that the nineteenth century westward movement over the California National Historic Trail was a significant event in the development of the western United States, involving over 300,000 settlers and preventing colonization by Russia and the British Empire. Additional recognition and interpretation of this movement is deemed appropriate. The California Trail, including the Hastings Cutoff and the trail of the ill-fated Donner-Reed Party, is recognized for its national, historical, and cultural significance. The Act aims to provide an interpretive facility highlighting the vital role of the California Trail and other trails in the West in the development of the United States. The Act defines key terms such as "California Trail," "Center," "Secretary," and "State." It establishes the California Trail Interpretive Center under section 4. The Secretary may establish the "California Trail Interpretive Center" near Elko, Nevada to preserve the history of the California Trail. A development plan must include details on design, site location, acquisition method, construction cost, and operation cost. The development plan for the California Trail Interpretive Center near Elko, Nevada must include the cost of operation and maintenance, as well as the involvement of non-Federal entities in acquisition, construction, and operation. Special considerations include considering findings from a master plan study and allowing for local review and input in the establishment process. The Advisory Board for the National Historic California Emigrant Trails Interpretive Center in Elko, Nevada provides input on the establishment and operation. The Secretary can acquire land for the Center through donation, purchase, or exchange. A budget for maintenance and operation is prepared periodically. Cooperative agreements can be made with the State for assistance in snow removal, rescue, firefighting, and law enforcement. The Secretary may accept donations of funds, property, or services from various entities to assist in establishing or operating the Center. Contributions for the Center can also be accepted from State and local sources during its construction. The Secretary may accept donations from State, local sources, and entities to establish and operate the Center. Contributions totaling $6,000,000 will be received from the State, Elko County, and the city of Elko, Nevada for the construction of the Center. The funds will be used to establish and operate the Center. Authorization of $12,000,000 for the Secretary to establish the Center.
